Could the water have covered Mount Everest?
 
 Mt Everest is almost 9 km (5.5 miles) high. How, then, could the Flood have covered 'all the high hills under the whole heaven'? 
 
 The Bible refers only to 'high hills,' and the mountains today were formed only towards the end of, and after, the Flood by collision of the tectonic plates and the associated upthrusting. In support of this, the layers that form the uppermost parts of Mt Everest are themselves composed of fossil-bearing, water-deposited layers.
 
 This uplift of the new continental land-masses from under the Flood waters would have meant that, as the mountains rose and the valleys sank, the waters would have rapidly drained off the newly emerging land surfaces. The collapse of natural dams holding back the floodwaters on the land would also have caused catastrophic flooding. Such rapid movement of large volumes of water would have caused extensive erosion and shaped the basic features of today's Earth surface. 
 The Olgas
 Kata Tjuta in central Australia is composed of material which must have been deposited quickly by water.
 
 Thus it is not hard to envisage the rapid carving of the landscape features that we see on the earth today, including places such as the Grand Canyon of the USA. The present shape of Uluru (Ayers Rock), a sandstone monolith in central Australia, is the result of erosion, following tilting and uplift, of previously horizontal beds of water-laid sand. The feldspar-rich sand that makes up Uluru must have been deposited very quickly and recently. Long-distance transport of the sand would have caused the grains to be rounded and sorted, whereas they are jagged and unsorted. If they had sat accumulating slowly in a lake bed drying in the sun over eons of time, which is the story told in the geological display at the park center, the feldspar would have weathered into clay. Likewise, if Uluru had sat in the once-humid area of central Australia for millions of years, it would have weathered to clay.21 Similarly, the nearby Kata Tjuta (The Olgas) are composed of an unsorted mixture of large boulders, sand and mud, indicating that the material must have been transported and deposited very rapidly.
 
 Receding floodwaters eroded the land, creating river valleys. This explains why rivers are often so much smaller than the valleys they flow in today-they did not carve the valleys. The water flow that carved out the river valleys must have been far greater than the volume of water we see flowing in the rivers today. This is consistent with voluminous Flood waters draining off the emerging land surfaces at the close of Noah's Flood, and flowing into the rapidly sinking, newly prepared, deep ocean basins.
 
 Our understanding of how the Flood could have occurred is continually developing. Ideas come and go, but the fact of the Flood remains. Genesis clearly testifies to it, Jesus and the Apostles confirmed it, and there is abundant global geological evidence for a global watery cataclysm.

Thomson's experiments that revealed the existence of the electron, and move on through Ernest Rutherford, whos experiments suggested that an atom had a dense positive nucleus with electrons orbiting about it and finally to Niels Bohr who demonstrated that the orbits consisted of discrete energy levels and that electons jumped from one to the next as the atom absorbed or released energy.

Try Roemer's experiments in the 1600's using the position of Jupiter's moons in relation to the orbit of the Earth. He measured it to around 296,000 Km/s (surprisingly accurate for the time). Experiments in the 1800s by Fizeau and Michaelson. using rotating mirrors further refined the measurements. You could even check it yourself using quite inexpensive equipment (see http://www.picotech.com/experiments/speed_of_light/ for example)
 
 
Oh yeah, scientists decided that light speed isnt a constant, because they somehow figured out that it travels a different velocity in different mediums. (Not a clue how they came up with that one)
It was easy. Foucault and Fizeau measured the speed of light using the rotating mirror technique through air and through water. They found that it traveled more slowly through water. These days we even understand why it travels more slowly through more dense materials. Crudely put, it is because light is made up of photons and when a photon hits an atom, it is absorbed, an electron jumps to a higher energy shell, collapses back and in the process releases a new photon that carries on it's way. This takes time and thus slows the light up. The more dense the material, the more often the photon hits an atom and thus the longer it takes to travel through it.

 It was easy. Foucault and Fizeau measured the speed of light using the rotating mirror technique through air and through water. They found that it traveled more slowly through water. These days we even understand why it travels more slowly through more dense materials. Crudely put, it is because light is made up of photons and when a photon hits an atom, it is absorbed, an electron jumps to a higher energy shell, collapses back and in the process releases a new photon that carries on it's way. This takes time and thus slows the light up. The more dense the material, the more often the photon hits an atom and thus the longer it takes to travel through it.

 So I'll give you examples of evolution - not shreds of evidence, but observations of actual evolutionary events. I guess you are either new to these boards or haven't been paying attention. I've mentioned them before, but I'll mention them again just for you.
 
 Apples are not native to North America but were introduced from Europe. In the first half of the 19th century, John Chapman (Johnny Appleseed) traveled from Massachusetts to the Ohio valley carrying bags of apple seed. He traveled up and down the valley planting apples. Since the apples were an introduced plant, there were no natural pests. However, in the 1850s worms began to appear in apples. Investigation found that they were the larvae of small flies that appeared identical to hawthorn maggot flies. But the life cycle of these flies was closely linked to the time that the host plant set fruit. They matured and were sexually active only during those few days each year, and hawthorn and apples set fruit at times separated by several weeks. Studies have shown that hawthorn maggot flies and apple maggot flies do not interbreed, in fact cannot since they are sexually active at times separated by weeks. This is a speciation event. It has happened at least twice more with similar maggot flies that now infest pears and cherrys, two other introduced plants. We might note that maggot flies do not infest other plants like the citrus plants. They are limited strictly to members of the rose family of plants. Not unexpected from an evolutionary standpoint.
 
 The herring gull shares its range with the lesser black-backed gull, the herring gull ranging to the west from northern Europe, and the lesser black-backed gull to the east. The herring gull population extends across the Atlanatic to Iceland, southern Greenland and North America. The American herring gull can be found across the northern part of the continent to Alaska, where it meets the Vega herring gull in Siberia, which meets Birula's gull, which meets Heuglin's gull, which meets the Siberian lesser black-backed gull, which meets the lesser black-backed gull. At all points, the various populations are capable of interbreeding (and do interbreed) and produce fertile off spring. Except the herring gull and the lesser black-backed gull do not interbreed. Even though they are at the extremes of a single population that encircles the globe, they have been classified as separate species. An event that wiped out herring gulls in North America would be a speciation event.
 
 The same has been observed in a population of salamanders that encircles California's central valley, and in a species of warbler that encircles the Tibeten plateau.
 
 Fruit flies used in laboratory genetics studies are all derived from a single strain from California. It has been discovered that strains that have been maintained in isolation from others of identical ancestry can no longer interbreed. Nor can the laboratory strains interbreed with the original parent population. More speciation events that occurred when populations were isolated.
 
 Polar bears and brown bears can interbreed and do produce fertile offspring. The two species can be distinguished by genetic analysis, except for the brown bears of the ABC islands of Alaska. They cannot be distinguished genetically from polar bears although they appear no different from any other brown bear.
